title: Between 1 April 2018 and 31 March 2019, will an armed group from the Central African Republic engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in the Central African Republic?
preds: Changing forecast. It appears that things are heating up in CAR.

A UN report found that the civil war in CAR has been intensifying in the past two months and has spread to nearly the whole country, including the capital. The number of IDPs has increased by 70%. A recent situation report (in French) from the Famine Early Warning network states that more than 3261 acts of violence against civilians and aid workers has been recorded in the first trimester of the year. Notable incidents thus far include an attack on churches and hospitals in Bangui at the beginning of May that resulted in 19 deaths and attacks by Christian militias near the DRC border in mid-May that resulted an estimated 30 deaths.  https://www.voanews.com/a/central-african-republic-continues-slide-to-full-scale-war/4413093.html https://reliefweb.int/report/central-african-republic/r-publique-centrafricaine-key-message-update-l-acc-s-aux-aliments https://www.apnews.com/c571b7040f654e268e232f323667bc74/Death-toll-in-Central-African-Republic's-capital-rises-to-19 http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/central-african-republic-attacks-target-muslims-death-toll-1.4114932
The numbers just won't add up to 1,000

The UN reports 7000 Central Africans have fled into the DRC following an outbreak of violence. I have not found any sources able to confirm the nature of the violence or the belligerents at the present moment. But where there is smoke there is fire.  http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-05/19/c_137189791.htm

Edit on May 26th, 2018 : due to more killings in May 2018, amendements must be made.  There will be more killings in CAR before 2019, and the numbers will easily reach 1000 dead : but will these be targeting civilians in a single campaign, as defined in EWP guidelines? Factors that include an increase of tension include : 
- Between 2013 and 2015, the UN concluded that there was between 3000 and 6000 dead  (but it was not labelled "genocide" and would not answer the definition).
- In April 2018, about 30 people were killed in attacks led bu the CAR forces and the MINUSCA jointly.  In May, there have been at least 25 dead in the PK5 district of Bangui. More tensions are to be predicted : the 1000 people mark will be easily reached incrementally. Should tensions reflame, this mark might also be reached. 
- EU and French missions to bring peace have been retreating and ceding prerogatives to MINUSCA but their track record for peacekeeping is lower. 
- Russian "advisors" have been working in collaboration with the CAR government but they have no incentive (historical, religious or economic) to prevent killings should they take place. 
- In 2013, Seleka members were estimated at 12 000 people ; anti-balaka ranged from 20 000 to 75 000 : killings in these two rival factions only could total higher than 1000 but civilians would not be directly targeted as per EWP definition. 
- In 2017, more than 80% of the country was divided under the control or influence of one of the 14 armed groups.  Limitations : 
At once, killings tend to be less than 50 people killed at once. Those deaths are almost always framed as combattant death. Mass killings reach the hundreds but it remains unlikely that a mass campaign would kill 1000 civilians in one go and in once location.  Sources (all in French) : 
Numbers : http://www.irinnews.org/fr/report/100999/république-centrafricaine%C2%A0-la-crise-en-chiffres
UN Human Rights rapport : http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Countries/CF/Mapping2003-2015/2017CAR_Mapping_Report_FR.pdf
On Russians in Bangui : http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2018/04/23/la-russie-installe-peu-a-peu-sa-presence-dans-la-capitale-centrafricaine_5289462_3212.html
Division of CAR in factions : Nathalia Dukhan, « « En Centrafrique, les groupes armés prolifèrent grâce à une impunité totale » », Le Monde,‎ 21 août 2017
The number of active militia groups has increased dramatically, but thus far these groups appear to be targeting each other and not civilians.
